description: From Middle English ges, from Middle French gies, from the plural of jet (“throw”), from Vulgar Latin *iectus, jectus < iactus (“a throwing”), or from jeter (“to throw”), itself from Latin iactare.

entries.meaning: (falconry) A short strap fastened around the leg of a bird used in falconry, to which a leash may be fastened.
examples: Haukes haue about theyr legges gesses made of lether moste comonly, some of silke which should no lenger but that the knottes of them should appere in ye myddes of the left hande betwene the longe fynger and the leche fynger bicause the lewnes should be fastened to them with a payre of tyrettes, whiche tyrettes should rest vpon the lewnes and not vpon gesses, for hangyng and fastyng vpon trees when she fleyth  […]

verbs.description: jess (third-person singular simple present jesses, present participle jessing, simple past and past participle jessed)

entries.meaning: (falconry) To fasten a strap around the leg of a hawk.
